subject: Art
title: Choosing Body Text
description: Selecting a typeface that readers can comfortably read for hours.

hook.text: Body text is the workhorse of typography ‚Äî it's what people actually read. A display font grabs attention; a body font holds it for pages. Choosing the right one is the most impactful typographic decision.

buildup.text: Body text requirements: excellent readability at small sizes, even color (no distractingly thick or thin strokes), good x-height, comfortable width (not too narrow or wide), and a complete character set.

discovery.text: Safe bets: Georgia or Charter (screen serif), Inter or Source Sans (screen sans), Garamond or Caslon (print serif), Helvetica or Frutiger (print sans). These are optimized for extended reading.

twist.text: The best body typeface is one you don't notice. If the reader becomes aware of the font while reading, it's doing its job poorly. Body type should be transparent ‚Äî a window to the content, not a wall.

climax.text: Test body text by reading an actual paragraph at actual size on the actual medium (screen or print). Don't judge body type from a specimen sheet ‚Äî judge it in context, at reading distance, for extended time.

punchline.text: Body text is invisible when perfect. If you notice the font, change it.

quiz.question: What is the most important quality of a body text typeface?
options: Excellent readability at small sizes for extended reading
